title: Saudi Arabia Shoots Down Missiles Over Capital, Yemen Border City
summary: Saudi officials suspect Iran-backed Houthi fighters in Yemen. DUBAI-Saudi air defenses shot down ballistic missiles fired at the country's capital and a city along its southern border with Yemen, according to Saudi officials, who blamed Iran-backed Houthi forces in Yemen.

title: President's Equipment Czar to Use Full Powers to Fight Coronavirus
summary: Peter Navarro says most companies ready to cooperate but president ready to knock down obstacles 'unmercifully'. WASHINGTON-Peter Navarro, the Trump administration adviser chosen to oversee its wartime powers forcing private businesses into the fight against the coronavirus pandemic, said the full arsenal of federal measures are on the table, from raids on warehouses to compelling suppliers to retool factories.

title: Exodus of Workers Reveals the Limits of India's Coronavirus Lockdown
summary: Hundreds of thousands of out-of-work people began walking to distant homes or crowded onto buses out of cities. NEW DELHI-Days after India declared a nationwide lockdown to slow the spread of the coronavirus, hundreds of thousands of out-of-work migrant laborers began walking to homes sometimes hundreds of miles away and jammed together waiting for rides in packed buses.

title: Thomas Allen Coburn
summary: The doctor and Senator was the model of a citizen legislator.. Politics is a lifetime career for most in American government, and then there are exceptions like Thomas Coburn. The Oklahoma obstetrician who became a Senator and then returned to a productive private life died Saturday of prostate cancer at age 72. He was what America's Founders imagined in self-governing citizen legislators, and that mentality made him far more consequential than the usual congressional seat-fillers.

title: New York Postpones Democratic Primary to June 23
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo says the move is necessary to stem a tide of coronavirus infections. New York will move its presidential primary from April to late June as deaths stemming from the new coronavirus pandemic escalate sharply.

title: Russia's Rosneft Plans to Sell All Assets Related to Venezuela
summary: Move comes weeks after Trump administration added a subsidiary of Rosneft to its financial blacklist for allegedly helping Venezuela sell its oil in violation of U.S. sanctions. MOSCOW-In an unexpected move, Russian state oil giant Rosneft announced that it would halt all activities in Venezuela and sell all its assets related to activities in the country.

title: Brother of Jeff Bezos' Girlfriend Sues National Enquirer Publisher
summary: Michael Sanchez's lawsuit says publisher defamed him when it claimed that he was the source of the tabloid's 2019 exposé. Michael Sanchez, the brother of Jeff Bezos' girlfriend, is alleging in a lawsuit that the publisher of the National Enquirer defamed him when it claimed that he was the source of the tabloid's 2019 exposé about the Amazon.com Inc. founder's extramarital affair.

title: Coburn's Principles
summary: The GOP needs more Senators with his conviction and judgment.. Editor's note: Former Oklahoma Senator Tom Coburn died Saturday at age 72. We published this editorial on Jan. 20, 2014 when he announced his retirement from the Senate:

title: Athletes Who Qualified for Tokyo 2020 Will Keep Spots in Delayed Games
summary: Many qualified U.S. teams, such as women's soccer and gymnastics, have secured spots but won't name rosters for months. After a few days of confusion, it became clear Saturday that teams and athletes who have qualified for spots in the Tokyo 2020 Olympics will keep those slots whenever in 2021 the postponed Games take place.

title: Tokyo Olympics Likely to Start July 2021
summary: The Games are being delayed by around a year because of the coronavirus pandemic. TOKYO-Organizers of the summer Olympics in Tokyo are in the final stages of settling on a July 2021 start to the Games, several major Japanese news organizations reported, citing officials involved in the process.

title: Pandemic Has Army Paying Recruits Even Before Boot Camp
summary: Contagion has upended recruiting, prompting stopgaps to manage delayed start dates and stranded volunteers. The Army is planning to put some new enlistees on the payroll even before they ship out for boot camp, an unusual stopgap to maintain recruiting amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Priests, Rabbis, Imams Wrestle With Coronavirus Constraints
summary: Lockdowns lead to drive-through confessions, calls to prayer at home and assembling minyans virtually. At mosques around the world, the muezzins who ordinarily call Muslims to prayer five times a day are enjoining the faithful to pray at home, for the first time since Islam's Prophet Muhammad in the seventh century.

title: Gun-Rights Activist Releases Blueprints for Digital Guns
summary: Cody Wilson calls the move impervious to legal challenge. A U.S. technology company made thousands of digital-gun files publicly available, including blueprints that will enable users to make plastic guns with three-dimensional printers, a scourge of gun-control advocates.

title: SoftBank's Satellite Startup OneWeb Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
summary: The satellite broadband venture said it couldn't secure financing while the coronavirus outbreak roils financial markets. Satellite venture OneWeb Global Ltd. has filed for bankruptcy after raising more than $3.4 billion from SoftBank Group Corp. , Airbus SE and other investors to build a satellite network that would beam cheap internet connectivity from space.

title: Former Sen. Tom Coburn, a Political Maverick, Dies After Cancer Battle
summary: Elected to the U.S. House in 1994 and later the Senate, he fiercely criticized the use of federal money for special state projects. OKLAHOMA CITY-Former U.S. Sen. Tom Coburn, an Oklahoma family doctor who earned a reputation as a conservative political maverick as he railed against federal earmarks and subsidies for the rich, has died. He was 72.

title: Two Best Friends and the Global Treasure Hunt for Coronavirus Supplies
summary: 'People will pay anything' for scarce protective gear. SAN FRANCISCO-Jake Medwell and Drew Oetting, roommates in this city's Russian Hill neighborhood, usually start each morning with an intense partner workout and shots of apple cider vinegar. This past Tuesday began with a frantic phone call from the State Department.

title: Civil-Rights Leader Joseph Lowery Dies at 98
summary: Fiery Alabama preacher in 2009 was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom. ATLANTA-The Rev. Joseph E. Lowery fought to end segregation, lived to see the election of the country's first black president and echoed the call for "justice to roll down like waters and righteousness like a mighty stream" in America.

title: A Global Downturn Will Test Investors' Taste for Liquor
summary: Shares of liquor brands have fallen less than brewers during the Covid-19 outbreak. Investors are showing a preference for liquor stocks over beer in the global health crisis. A drawn-out recession might change their tastes.

title: The '70s-Inspired Sunshine of Spring's Styles
summary: Slow, sunny days call for delicate lace and crocheted knits that have a romantic vibe. SPRING AWAKENING A brief encounter with pale hues is sweetly charming. Celine by Hedi Slimane top, $2,450, celine.com, She Made Me briefs, $70, shemademe.com

title: Watch This Corner of the Mortgage Market Closely
summary: What happens to mortgage-investment firms will shed light on what may be in store for the rest of the market. Among the hardest-hit victims of funding-market troubles have been mortgage-investment firms. What happens to them will shed light on what may be in store for the rest of the market.

title: Ways Older Adults Can Cope With the Stress of Coronavirus
summary: A psychologist specializing in older people gives advice on how they can handle the threat and uncertainty-and how their adult children and others can help. With the new coronavirus targeting older adults, how can they best cope and how can their adult children help them?

title: How Coronavirus Has Changed New York City's Transit Landscape
summary: As people worked from home and fewer commute, normally busy areas have shown less congestion. In New York City, one of the largest urban areas in the world, traffic is part of daily life. But since the outbreak of the novel coronavirus, the hectic and congested landscape of the city has gradually changed as more people work from home and fewer commute.

title: New York City Must Shield Homeless From Coronavirus, Legal Aid Says
summary: Spokesman for Department of Social Services says city is working quickly to 'implement unprecedented solutions'. Advocates are calling on New York City to provide hotel rooms for tens of thousands of homeless people so they can practice social distancing and self-quarantine in the epicenter of the nation's new coronavirus crisis.

title: Coronavirus and Autocrats: Never Let Pandemic Go to Waste
summary: For authoritarian-minded leaders world-wide, health emergency presents opportunity to weaken democracy. With much of the world on lockdown, the coronavirus pandemic has chipped away at individual liberties everywhere. In more places, however, it is also being used as an excuse to weaken democratic institutions and oversight-an authoritarian slide that could endure once the current health emergency subsides.

title: More States Charge Fees for Electric Vehicles
summary: The levies are meant to make up for lost gas taxes, but some say they conflict with promoting energy efficiency. More states are imposing special registration fees on electric vehicles, sparking complaints that the levies undermine efforts to get consumers to embrace alternative-fuel cars.

title: Old Laptop, Tablet or Phone? Here's How They Can Help You Right Now
summary: Thanks to the Great Stay-at-Home Experiment of 2020, gadgets are backordered, but there's plenty you can do with your old ones. Calling all Marie Kondo defiers! Yes, you, who fought the good fight and refused to part with that crusty, dusty 9,000-pound laptop in your basement that we both know sparks absolutely no joy.

title: Wall Street Says Some Duties Can't Be Done From Home
summary: Fingerprinting and reconciling stockholders' records are cumbersome tasks during coronavirus lockdowns. WASHINGTON-The new coronavirus hasn't shut down financial markets, thanks to electronic trading. But some tasks on Wall Street, it turns out, aren't made for social distancing.

title: The Treasures of France's Most Revered Gardener
summary: Landscape designer Louis Benech on the objects he can't live without. "In the front, the round plastic object is a planisphere-a map of the sky-that belonged to my maternal grandmother. It made me dream as a child. Near the back, leaning on the vase, is an alga from an herbarium of strange, incredible shapes, which could have been invented by Max Ernst. The vase is by Laurent Esquerré, given to me by a couple of decorators, Daniel Suduca and Thierry Merillou. If I had no idea of what to do with a house, I would ask them. The book next to that is a volume of W.J. Bean's Trees & Shrubs Hardy in the British Isles-stories about trees that help you to memorize botanical descriptions. What Bean did, which is marvelous, is that he added anecdotes and short stories about each plant. As a teenager, I read it like a novel or a livre des fées. The balsa-wood arch leaning against it is something I made when we redesigned the Tuileries Gardens. In front of that is an ashtray that belonged to my paternal grandmother, who was always smoking, smoking, smoking. She kept this next to her récamière, where she lay down after lunch. Sitting inside of that is a pillbox carved out of walnut wood to look like a walnut-a perfect copy, given to me by [gallerist] Pierre Passebon. I bought the gourds next to it in Cusco, Peru. Behind them is a tiny bust of a man shouting, which was given to me by Christian Louboutin. It's extremely expressive. The chap who did that sculpture [Jean-Noël Lavesvre] did a portrait of me like a village boy-naked, tattooed-which is sitting in Christian's shop in New York. The large photograph in front is by the photographer Karl Blossfeldt. It is one of six of my naughty, dirty pictures of equisetum, or horsetails. It's either very funny or extremely phallic. Blossfeldt loved how architectural nature could be. He was amazed by the composition of what God-if there is one-is doing."

title: Gas Suppliers Face Soaring Demand for Oxygen to Treat Coronavirus Patients
summary: Air Liquide and Air Products say they are exploring ways to avert logistical bottlenecks. Two of the world's biggest suppliers of medical oxygen, Air Liquide SA and Air Products & Chemicals Inc., say they are exploring ways to ensure supplies of the gas remain sufficient for treatment of Covid-19 patients.

title: Coronavirus Rule Breakers Draw Public Ire Online
summary: Internet users name and shame people they believe have flouted lockdown orders, traveled or socialized recklessly. As the movements of vast swaths of the global population are restricted due to the coronavirus pandemic, those who test the limits of quarantines and social distancing are drawing a fierce backlash online.

title: Coronavirus Silences the Concert Industry
summary: List of postponements grows by the day: Pearl Jam, Billie Eilish, Celine Dion, Rolling Stones. The concert industry was supposed to have its best year ever, highlighted by tours including the Rolling Stones, Elton John and Post Malone. Now, it's hard to say when the next show will take place.

title: Small Business Administration's New Boss Has Big Job Ahead
summary: Jovita Carranza, highest-ranking Latina in Trump administration, will oversee $349 billion SBA loan program. WASHINGTON-Jovita Carranza, the newly appointed head of the Small Business Administration, just found herself leading the charge in one front in the epic battle against the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Who's Left Out of Stimulus Payments? Many College Students, Adult Dependents
summary: Money will go to adults and children, but millions of others won't get paid. WASHINGTON-The government is preparing to send one-time payments to most Americans to help them cope with the coronavirus outbreak, but that is little comfort for many college students and adult dependents who are left out.

title: Small Businesses Struggle With SBA Disaster Loan Applications
summary: Owners can't gain access to agency's online site or get bounced off too soon. The Small Business Administration's disaster loan program for small businesses has gotten off to a rocky start, with businesses hit by the coronavirus pandemic complaining about an inability to file their loan applications online.

title: Getting Exercise in the Mountains Where They Can Find It
summary: A Colorado family finds ways to get outdoors for fitness and relaxation as coronavirus limits their options. Like many people, Seth Sachson has been struggling with how to exercise responsibly and safely during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Staying Inside Guide: Through a Screen, Sharply
summary: Some museum websites offer close encounters with the masterpieces you're missing.. Art museums' collection databases, slideshows of highlights, and tours available on their websites are wonderful resources. But with these institutions now closed I wondered if, as well, there was a kind of substitute art experience to be found on them. Could the virtual world offer the same close-quarters, in-depth encounter with a single object that is the essence of the bricks-and-mortar visit? Taking into account the standard caveat that a reproduction is no substitute for the original, the answer is yes. A number of videos, ranging in length from 90 seconds to 10 minutes, offer encounters as immediate and engaging, albeit in a different way, as those you get before a display case. Herewith a selection of some of the best.

title: Lawmakers Pack Federal Stimulus Bill With Pet Provisions
summary: Special-interest beneficiaries of the $2 trillion stimulus package range from sunscreen makers to seafood companies. WASHINGTON-The roughly $2 trillion stimulus package passed by Congress provides big-ticket relief to workers and businesses-and a lot of small favors to special interests.

title: People Need Loans. Lenders Are Making Them Tougher to Get.
summary: As a possible recession looms, banks and fintech companies are tightening lending standards for small businesses and riskier consumers. Banks and financial-technology firms are starting to toughen their approval standards for new loans to consumers and small businesses. That means many people could find it hard to get credit just when they most need it, as the novel coronavirus pandemic puts thousands out of work.

title: Bringing Home a New Baby-and the New Coronavirus
summary: Two infected parents, wrestling three children and a newborn, try to stay close from a safe distance. Tamar Weinberger saw her three kids playing outside their home in Teaneck, N.J., as her car rolled up the driveway. The children, 10, 7 and 3 years old, converged on the car, anxious to meet the newest member of their family, a baby boy. But Tamar quickly whisked the new baby out of their reach.

title: Economic-Stimulus Checks Differ From Past Interventions
summary: The one-time cash distribution won't boost economic output as similar programs in the past aimed to do, but it could limit its likely steep drop. Americans want the federal government to show them the money-and lawmakers are eager to do just that.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Rescue Boosts Capital for Global Recovery
summary: Economic aid legislation signed by President Trump bolsters IMF and World Bank. WASHINGTON-The economic aid legislation signed by President Trump on Friday bolsters the international lending institutions that are gearing up for an unprecedented bailout of the global economy.

title: Coronavirus Forces Courts to Experiment
summary: Attorneys and judges are encountering glitches as they attempt to teleconference trials and work out plea deals by video. In Florida, an attorney learned late one afternoon that her trial in three days would be held over a video-conferencing technology she had never used. In Texas, a judge emptied a courtroom to allow a defendant calling in by phone to confer privately with his attorney.

title: Amy Compton-Phillips: A New Frontier for Medical Technology
summary: Telehealth systems are growing rapidly in response to the crisis. Around 8 p.m. on Jan. 20, I received the call: A test had confirmed that one of the hospitals where I oversee clinical care, in Everett, Wash., had admitted the first Covid-19 patient in the U.S. The coronavirus bomb went off in our corner of the country that day, and we quickly realized that the pandemic would change health care faster than anything before. We are now leveraging telehealth technology in ways that will last long after this pandemic.

title: Jamil Zaki: Habits of Kindness That Will Endure
summary: Disasters shock us into remembering our shared humanity. I know it feels impossible, but try to think back to the ancient past-sometime in 2019, before you had heard of the coronavirus. Back then, how would you have predicted people would respond to a sudden global pandemic? You might have imagined a scene from "Contagion" or "Panic in the Streets"-mobs looting pharmacies, neighbor ruthlessly turning on neighbor.

title: Virus Pushes Trump to Rose Garden Strategy
summary: As he leads daily coronavirus briefings with the White House as backdrop, the approach appears to be paying political dividends. Sometimes presidents choose to adopt a Rose Garden strategy to campaign for re-election, opting to make their case with the White House as a dramatic backdrop.

title: Government Tracking How People Move Around in Pandemic
summary: Goal is to get location data in up to 500 U.S. cities to help plan response; privacy concerns call for 'strong legal safeguards,' activist says. WASHINGTON-Government officials across the U.S. are using location data from millions of cellphones in a bid to better understand the movements of Americans during the coronavirus pandemic and how they may be affecting the spread of the disease.

title: W. Bradford Wilcox: Marriage With Family at Its Center
summary: In trying times, spouses realize that the core of their relationship is caring for children, relatives and one another. On March 13-the day my wife informed me that our weekend date night was off because our governor had declared a state of emergency-I had an inkling that big changes were in store for our marriage. A few days later, as we found ourselves barely managing to home-school six children, work two jobs and run a big household on lockdown, I knew that the loss of a regular date night was going to be the least of our marital challenges. Scenarios like ours-and ones much, much harder, with millions of parents losing jobs, heading to the front lines to battle the virus or grieving the loss of loved ones-are playing out in homes across America.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: ICUs Leverage Remote Doctors and Telemedicine to Manage Coronavirus Deluge
summary: Hospitals fast-track remote technology to manage a deluge of critically ill Covid-19 patients-and protect on-site health-care workers. As American cities face a surge of coronavirus patients who will require lifesaving care, they are also facing a rapidly dwindling supply of available intensive-care-unit beds. Physicians and nurses at many of the country's largest hospital systems are leveraging a decades-old technology in new ways-at times coupling it with cheap, readily available gadgets-to expand their ability to care for and monitor patients.

title: Where Markets Go From Here: Wall Street's Biggest Names Weigh In
summary: They've navigated selloffs and downturns, natural disasters and terrorist attacks. Now they're advising investors on what's coming next-and what they can do about it.. Wall Street's seasoned executives have navigated market selloffs and economic downturns, disruptive hurricanes and even terrorist attacks. Many of them stood at the precipice in 2008, when the financial system they had helped lead faced one of its biggest challenges ever.

title: We Can't Prevent Market Panics. We Can Control How We React.
summary: The dangers lurking in the market can be hidden or delayed, but never eliminated. For investors, slumps are a chance for introspection-and, sometimes, new opportunity.. How could a microscopic organism destroy nearly $15 trillion in global stock-market wealth in five weeks?

title: Ginnie Mae to Help Mortgage Firms Facing Coronavirus Cash Crunch
summary: U.S. agency aims to get cash to companies that expect a wave of missed payments. Ginnie Mae, a U.S. agency that guarantees more than $2 trillion of mortgage-backed securities, said it is working to help mortgage companies facing a severe cash crunch when borrowers fall behind in their payments because of measures to contain the novel coronavirus pandemic.

title: Ex-Venezuelan General Surrenders to U.S. After Drug Indictment
summary: Cliver Alcalá is expected to collaborate with U.S. prosecutors building cases against others in Venezuelan regime. BOGOTÁ, Colombia-Retired Venezuelan Gen. Cliver Alcalá turned himself in to the U.S. counternarcotics authorities Friday, a day after U.S. prosecutors indicted him and other Venezuelan officials, including President Nicolás Maduro, on drug-trafficking charges, according to four people familiar with the matter.

title: Trump Authorizes Mobilization of Ready Reserve
summary: President's authorization requires Defense Department to scour its records of up to one million reservists. President Trump signed an executive order Friday that authorizes the Pentagon to identify and potentially reinstate to active duty former military medical personnel and other specialized reservists to help the nation counter the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Trump Orders GM to Make Ventilators
summary: President invokes Defense Production Act, which allows his administration to mobilize certain industries. WASHINGTON- President Trump ordered General Motors Co. to sharply ramp up the production of ventilators to treat coronavirus patients, turning to a wartime presidential power that he had been reluctant to use.

title: Lawmakers Leave Washington Without Renewing Surveillance Powers
summary: Intelligence and law-enforcement experts warn the FBI now lacks a critical tool. WASHINGTON-House lawmakers left town Friday after passing a roughly $2 trillion dollar coronavirus relief package without voting to renew a set of intelligence powers that expired earlier this month, meaning surveillance tools used by the FBI to pursue terrorism suspects will likely remain defunct for at least several more weeks.

title: Fox Business Parts Ways With Host Trish Regan
summary: Other hosts at Fox News have come under fire for minimizing the threat of coronavirus before changing tack. Fox Corp.'s business channel said it parted ways with host Trish Regan, who was taken off the air two weeks ago after she dismissed concerns over the coronavirus pandemic as "impeachment all over again."

title: Lynn Tilton Resigns From Control of Struggling Businesses
summary: Zohar CLO funds, owed $1.7 billion by a collection of Ms. Tilton-run companies, will take charge in bankruptcy. Turnaround manager Lynn Tilton has walked away from a collection of troubled businesses she has managed for years after being ordered to sell them to pay off Zohar funds, lenders that have sued her.

title: A Week of Coronavirus Pain and Progress
summary: Infections are rising, but markets are calmer and medical aid is surging.. As the number of Americans infected with the coronavirus surges, and hospitals are besieged, it can appear that America is losing the pandemic war. But in important ways the U.S. is better off at the end of March than it was a week ago, and it's worth tracking the progress as well as the pain.

title: Trump Signs $2 Trillion Coronavirus Stimulus Package
summary: Party leaders overcome GOP lawmaker's last-minute delay effort. WASHINGTON-President Trump signed a roughly $2 trillion stimulus package into law, hours after House lawmakers hustled back to the Capitol to pass the aggressive response to the coronavirus pandemic that has staggered the U.S. economy.
